If keychain credentials are obsolete, prompt popup to manually enter correct ones & update keychain

fields.description:
After adding the GitLab.com account in the Preferences I am continually asked for password (sometimes several times in succession) even though I always enter the correct private token that I created specifically for Sourcetree.

 

If I had to guess, I would say that it likely has to do with how the keychain is used from the Sourcetree app.  Since I also have my gitlab.com credentials stored in keychain for the browser to use, it is my guess that there is a collision in the Sourcetree app when it tries to save the credentials to keychain.  Sourcetree is going to need to store them in Keychain using some attributes that will not collide with any credentials already stored.

 

Of course, this may not be the case, but at the moment, using GitLab.com account with Sourcetree is not working because the Sourcetree app is constantly asking me to re-enter the "password" (even though it needs a private token), and does not remember the credential even though I check the box.
fields.summary: GitLab.com Private Token Not Stored

fields.description:
Unfortunately, I am not able to reliably reproduce this issue at will, but it _does_ happen frequently.
h3. Problem

Often, when I click in the left sidebar (e.g. *File status*, *History*, or a branch name), the item in the sidebar gets highlighted, but the content of the main window does not update to reflect the new selection.

I can't say this for certain, but I'm pretty sure that when it does happen, it is on the first click after switching back to SourceTree after working in another application.
h3. Workaround

Clicking a different item in the sidebar, then re-clicking the original selection, has always worked to get the contents of the main window to update properly.

However, this happens frequently and I'm pretty certain I have seen this at least since 3.0 and possibly even with the 2.x versions. I'm currently running macOS 10.14.6 Mojave.
fields.summary: content of main window does not update properly

fields.description:
Since SRCTREE-4343 is closed, un-fixed, I'm creating this to bring attention back to this issue. Source tree still doesn't do this.

 

I've posted the following notes as a comment in 4343, but I'm copying here for the sake of posterity.
 

Yubikey's on mac/linux use the SSH_AUTH_SOCK environment variable to refer ssh to the GPG agent for private keys. Most users run the GPG agent and set this variable in their ~/.bash_profile

Change sourcetree so the shell window opens an actual shell, or at least loads the .bash_profile before running git and it will work correctly with yubikey and other hardware security modules.
fields.summary: Sourcetree Git doesn't load .bash_profile, so ssh agents don't work, which breaks yubikey, etc...

fields.description:
Git processes spawned by SourceTree are not kill properly, resulting in a mass of "dead" processes named *git*, *git-remote-https* or *git-credential-sourcetree*.

They seem to be spawned every few minutes, when SourceTree refreshes the repo history by itself.

After 15+ processes spawned, SourceTree interface starts to be sluggish, and at some point it just freezes.

Only way to have it work smoothly again is to manually `killall -HUP git`.

 

NB: Severity is major, but since its on the 2.7 branch, idk if its prioritary.
fields.summary: git processes not cleaned up

fields.description:

The view has three columns: The left most one is the grey workspace pane, incl. the branches, remotes, etc. The second one are the two fields for staged and unstaged files. The third one is the diff window.

When I now try to resize the different columns to my needs, the other two columns get automatically resized as well and this resizing does not work for me at all. I can make the column with the un-/staged files a maximum of maybe 300px in width, before the other columns magically gain width as well, making the column that I actually want to increase (the file one) effectively smaller. This is super annoying.

This behavior has emerged very recently and, unfortunately, breaks Sourcetrees staging and diff functionality for me. I am switching to the terminal for now and hope that this gets resolved as soon as possible.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Sourcetree for Mac doesn't allow spaces in usernames when trying to access Bitbucket Server. Bitbucket Server does indeed accept them so this creates an error every time a user with a space in his username tries to use Sourcetree.

On the other hand, Sourcetree for Windows does currently allow spaces in the username.
h3. Workaround

Users will need to temporarily remove any spaces from their username.
fields.summary: Having spaces on username results on error

It's not clear where it is and requires hunting. Why not make it possible to directly access the functions from the dialog box itself so we don't have to go hunting around multiple clicks to get back to where you just told us we should go (without being clear or helping us get there).

It may seem like a small thing but it was pretty much almost the last straw for me as a new user trying to determine whether I should commit to learning what already looks and feels like a frustrating mess of a confusing UI to me.

fields.description:
If you connect your GitHub account with OAuth, SourceTree is only able to pull from public repos. It cannot push to public repos, and can't access private repos at all. This is because SourceTree requests the wrong permission set (it ONLY requests public read permissions, which is totally insufficient for a Git frontend).
h3. Workaround

There's no workaround at the moment.
fields.summary: When connecting to Github we can only access public repositories

fields.description:
This was the use case provided by  Robert Hobkirk from SSP-37927, I'm creating on behalf of the Robert as Robert was restricted from creating the bug ticket on JAC for SourceTree
{quote}
There appears to be an issue during the SourceTree registration process whereby users can't register with SSO for Bitbucket Server..

Our users don't have access to their passwords for logging in to BitBucket and instead we need to be able to register with SSO. This appears to be missing and means that our users can't register and therefore are unable to use SourceTree.

Am I missing something, or is this functionality missing? I've reported this as a bug since it's a regression from earlier versions of SourceTree.

I've checked the Getting Started docs (https://confluence.atlassian.com/get-started-with-sourcetree/install-sourcetree-847359094.html\) but they still show the earlier version of SourceTree.

To reproduce - install SourceTree, follow the registration process and click BitBucket Server. There is no SSO option here and it requires a Username / Password.
{quote}
 !Sourcetree-registration.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Registration of SourceTree using BitBucket Server and SSO

fields.description:
Valid URLs in a Git repo's commit message are not clickable in my version of SourceTree for Mac. This is annoying since it means I need to copy URLs in the commit message and paste them manually into the address bar of my browser in order to view them. Compare this with running `git log` in iterm2/zsh where I am able to cmd+click the link to navigate to the URL. 

The use case for me is that we are using Gerrit with a commit hook that automatically adds a link to the code review page in the commit message. If hyperlinks were clickable, I would be able to easily view the code review page directly from the link in the commit message (which is possible using `git log` as mentioned above)

Steps to reproduce:
 # Initialize new repo and make some change
 # `git commit -m "Link: https://www.google.com"`
 # View commit in SourceTree history, link is not clickable

Expected behavior:
 * Valid URLs in commit messages should be clickable and open in the browser (like links in commit messages viewed in `git log` from iterm2/zsh)

Thank you!
fields.summary: Make valid URLs in commit message clickable and open in browser

fields.description:
The behavior of _Shift-Command-C_ is context-dependent.
 # If you don't have staged files, this shortcut gets [the cursor] to the "Commit message" text box (without further ado). This is nice, because the shortcut places the cursor at the first writable position, so you can continue where you left off if you already have some text there.
 # If you have staged files and there is text in the "Commit message" text box, this shortcut will commit the staged files immediately (and will push them immediately if you have checked "Push changes immediately . . .")
 # If you have staged files but you don't have a Commit message in the "Commit message" text box, this shortcut will attempt to commit and will warn you that the Commit Message is empty (if you haven't checked "Do not show this message again"). 

It would be convenient to have the possibility of two separate shorctuts that would always behave consistently, regardless of context:
 # A shortcut that does (1) regardless of the state of Staged Files. 
 # A different shortcut that does (2) and, if you don't have a commit message, warns you with (3)

Thank you.
fields.summary: Keyboard Shortcut(s) for Commit and Commit message

fields.description:
I'm running MacOS 10.14.6.  I use Sourcetree with remote accounts on both Bitbucket and GitHub.  I recently needed to add a repository from GitHub.  The first problem I noticed was that I could not use the Remote Desktop to clone the repository from GitHub, in spite of carefully entering my GitHub username and password.  It said it couldn't authenticate.  I tried adding my GitHub account in Sourcetree, then retried the clone, but got the same error.  I then used command line git to clone the repo successfully, then opened it in Sourcetree.  After making code changes, I did a push and was prompted for my password along with a checkbox to save the password to the keychain, which I checked.  After that, the push succeeded.  However each time I did a push, I was reprompted for the password each time.  Quitting and restarting Sourcetree didn't help; obviously the password was either not stored in the keychain, or failed to be retrieved from there.

h3. Workaround

A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Trying to perform any Git actions prompts for my credentials everytime

fields.description:
*TLDR: Let's allow users to delete tags in "History" listing by clicking backspace keyboard key.*

Currently, tag deletion is done via right-clicking menu or menu bar Repository > Tag and in both cases: a) it's difficult to find the latest tag (because sorting is not by semver but numeric, which is another issue, for the record); b) it's slow process and many tags can't be deleted at once.

Background: if an npm package monorepo with ~100 CI release is botched before packages are published, user will have to manually delete that many git tags from remote, then force-push and initiate CI publishing pipeline again.

It is perfectly safe to allow users to select a tag, and press backspace key to delete it. If you want, confirmation box can be shown, but also it can be turned off or not shown by default.

!select_and_delete.png!

Let's allow users to delete tags in "History" listing by clicking backspace keyboard key.
fields.summary: Select a tag in History listing and press backspace to delete it

fields.description:
When you select "Log Selected..." on a File, in order to track its history, you are prompted with a dialog, in which this bug occurs.

You can see a preview of the changes in the right panel, but it fails to do so if the file has been renamed.

You can only see a preview of the changes in a file, if the filename is the current one.
fields.summary: Follow Renamed Files in Log view doesn't preview files before they were renamed.

fields.description:
When re-opening previous windows on startup, SourceTree does not handle missing directories gracefully.

 

It throws up approximately four modal dialogues that must be clicked through before you can close the offending window.

 

Having a directory go away is quite common in certain workflows.  SourceTree should handle this situation by doing a check first and not restoring a window if the directory is no longer there.
fields.summary: Don't re-open missing directories on startup

fields.description:
In my global .gitconfig, I have `gpgsign = true` in the `[commit]` section.

This requires commits to be GPG signed.

In SourceTree, every time I set up a project, I have to open settings, tick "Enable GPG key signing for commits", and choose the (only available) key.

I then have to tick "Sign commit..." from the "Commit options" popup.

When signing is mandatory, and there is no ambiguity about what settings to use, it would be really useful if SourceTree defaulted to these settings.
fields.summary: Use correct defaults if gpgsign = true

fields.description: Suddenly getting "Connection refused" (http) and "Authentication failed" (https) when trying to push or pull. Changing host type of remote from Bitbucket to Unknown fixes this issue. However this change does not stick and must be reapplied every time.
fields.summary: Host type of remotes always revert to Bitbucket

fields.description:
Whereas a custom action "BBEdit" has been defined in Preferences -> Custom Actions panel, this action is not displayed in contextual menu Custom Actions, see  Capture d’écran 20190706a.png.

But the action is correctly displayed from the menu bar Actions -> Custom Actions, see  Capture d’écran 20190706b.png.
fields.summary: Defined action is not displayed in contextual menu Custom Actions.

fields.description:
A crash occurred when typing in commit message.

See once. See crash report in attached text file.

Activity before the crash:
 * launch Sourcetree app
 * double clic on a repository in Sourcetree main repo list
 * clic on commit button
 * start typing in message arera
fields.summary: Crash when typing in commit message.

fields.description:
If SourceTree is using the embedded mercurial, version 4.6.1, then when I try to push to my Bitbucket repository, I get an error:

 

"repository requires features unknown to this Mercurial: sparserevlog!"

 

On the other hand, if I use the system mercurial, which is 4.9.1, then push works, but pull may produce an error saying:

 

"failed to import extension hgext.hgflow from SourceTree.app/Contents/Resources/mercurial_local/hgext/hgflow.py: 'module' object has no attribute 'command'"
fields.summary: Problems with Bitbucket Mercurial using either embedded or system mercurial

fields.description:
SourceTree Language & Region settings:
 * Preferred language: English (U.S.)
 * Date format: System default
 * Use relative date formatting: yes

With the language settings described above, SourceTree behaves as if my keyboard layout was U.S., i.e.:
 * command+A (selecting all) perfoms command+Q (quit)
 * Typing 'a' in the commit field writes 'q'

 

With the same language settings in macOS 10.14, the issue does not occur.

Changing the preferred language to 'Automatic' changes the interface language to french and fixes the issue.
fields.summary: [macOS 10.15 beta] Wrong keyboard layout when using non-automatic language

fields.description:
if I compare two files via "External Diff" it works the first time.

But if I back to sourcetree before closing beyond compare and and try to make a second compare via "External Diff", one of the files can not be found in the appdata-folder.

(And the file is really not in the appdata-folder)
fields.summary: unable to open second file with external diff

fields.description:
The ellipses button in the author edit popup brings the user to the "Security" tab in repo preferences sheet instead of the "Advanced" tab (where the author settings can be changed)

 

See attachments.
fields.summary: The ellipses button in the edit author popup opens the wrong repo preferences tab

fields.description:
Closing a repository window does not properly dispose of the window resources. Namely, the closed window is still reported by the system API to enumerate windows [https://developer.apple.com/documentation/coregraphics/1455137-cgwindowlistcopywindowinfo] — this causes havoc with the screen reader I use for accessibility purposes. 

It is also probably a contributor to gradually increasing memory footprint which I experience over several days as I keep opening and closing different repos. At around 1GB of memory usage I choose to relaunch the app, which while workable, is a pity. 

A simple fix, assuming you are using NSWindows, would be to ensure that the NSWindow is released when the user closes the window, by configuring it as such and ensuring no spurious references exist to the window instances. [https://developer.apple.com/documentation/appkit/nswindow/1419062-isreleasedwhenclosed]

 

if something else is being used, the fix would be the same in principle— release precious resources vended by the window server when user closes the window, to avoid abandoned memory piling up and to allow users with accessibility needs to better use Sourcetree.

Happy to discuss further.
fields.summary: Opening and closing a repository should properly dispose the window.

fields.description: Sourcetree only allows me to add accounts using SSH with a key name of "id_rsa." If I have multiple SSH keys in ~/.ssh and name them differently than "id_rsa" there appears to be no way to select a different SSH key.
fields.summary: Can only use "id_rsa" SSH key when adding accounts

fields.summary: Rainbow App icon not intuitive

fields.description:
When you're a few days late to pull your repo, or when you got a root folder to rename, you'll reach a number of commits or a number of files that is systematically truncated when displayed as a badge. It only displays 4 digits, the 5th one is truncated and the other digits are lost.

On other places in the app, the whole value is visible.

For instance, from my screenshots, it's truncating the following values:
 * 110457 files to be added
 * 257485 commits to pull
fields.summary: Badge Number of Files/Commits is truncated

fields.description:
The rainbow icon is great: it brings a distinctive visibility that we never had before, as almost all my important apps have a blue icon already (Xcode, App Store, ...). And in the attached screenshot, you may not know the icon on the right, but it's actually a popular app in China.

 

So I'd like a setting in Sourcetree that would let us keep the rainbow icon all year long. Thank you. 🙏
fields.summary: Allow us to keep the rainbow icon all year long

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
h3. Environment
 * macOS 10.14.5
 * XCode 10.2.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Download Sourcetree
 # Click Log in with Bitbucket cloud using an account that hasn't been registered with Bitbucket cloud

h3. Expected Results

Bitbucket cloud directs the user to register the account, and the user can click Log in with Bitbucket cloud again in Sourcetree to complete the login
h3. Actual Results

Sourcetree hangs indefinitely and is completely unresponsive until it is force quit
h3. Notes

(Optional - If Necessary)
h3. Workaround

Force Quit Sourcetree and re-open it to log in with Bitbucket cloud
fields.summary: Sourcetree hangs indefinitely if an account hasn't been signed up for bitbucket cloud

fields.description: I can't change back the app icon to the default one. Very disrupting as I have trouble finding the Sourcetree app in my dock.
fields.summary: Cannot reinstate the default application icon

fields.description:
Hi, 

I can't change back the logo to the blue one. The rainbow one disrupts my work, as I got used to the blue one and now I have troubles finding the Source Tree Icon in my applications bar.
fields.summary: Unable to change logo to standard instead of the rainbow one

fields.description:
SourceTree Mac App also need to Enable extended integration with GitHub Enterprise.

i've found this issue(https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/SRCTREEWIN-1034?_ga=2.239873027.1443414222.1560414624-174747130.1560414624), but this is window application issue.

 

Mac app also nedd it, 'Add the ability to initiate pull requests for locally-hosted github for enterprise instances. The link should be very similar to github.com'.

 

we can't edit Host Root URL at GitHub Enterprise Host Type(grayed out textfield, therefore we have to create pull request in Website or what else.(not SourceTree)
fields.summary: Need to 'Enable extended integration with GitHub Enterprise' too!

fields.description:
Steps to repro

 
 # right click on a commit
 # select "Rebase children XXXX interactively..."
 # pick a commit
 # click "edit message"
 # type a nice long well thought out message
 # before you select "OK" click somewhere back in the "rebase" dialog
 # see that the edit commit message window closes !!!!
 # click "edit message" again
 # see that all your unsaved changes are gone
fields.summary: Clicking outside "edit commit message" dialog should not close dialog.

fields.description: Occasionally, clicking "File Status" in the sidebar does not change the view from the history to the commit view. However, clicking the "commit" toolbar icon seems to always work. Also, clicking "History" sometimes does not change the view either. In both these cases, the item is highlighted, but the view does not change. Sometimes, if the view is changed in alternate ways, the sidebar items will start working again. I've noticed it more often with the "File status" item than with "History". I have not determined a specific way to get this state to happen. I believe I first noticed this bug about 3-5 months ago.
fields.summary: "File Status" and "History" items in sidebar don't always work
